sections.procedure:
1.  The case originated in an application (no. 32074/14) against Romania lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Romanian national, Ms Luminiţa Zamfira Solcan (“the applicant”), on 17 April 2014.
2.  The applicant was represented by Ms A. Diaconescu, a lawyer practising in Iași. The Romanian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, most recently Mr. V. Mocanu, of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
3.  The applicant alleged, in particular, a breach of Article 8 of the Convention as a result of the failure of the authorities to allow her to attend her mother’s funeral during her involuntary hospitalisation in an inpatient psychiatric facility.
4.  On 1 September 2015 notice of the complaint under Article 8 of the Convention was given to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
sections.circumstances:
5.  The applicant was born in 1969 and is currently in a psychiatric facility in Pădureni-Grajduri.
6.  In 2005 she committed a murder in France. On 12 November 2007 the Mâcon County Court discontinued the criminal investigation against her on the grounds that she had committed the offence in a state of diminished responsibility. The medical experts diagnosed her as suffering from paranoid schizophrenia and concluded that her acts had been the result of paranoid delusions. Endorsing the experts’ findings that she posed a danger to the public on account of her mental health, the court ordered her placement in a psychiatric facility in France for an indefinite period of time.
7.  In 2011 the applicant lodged a request to be transferred to a similar psychiatric facility in Romania in order to be closer to her mother, who lived in Iaşi.
8.  By a decision of 30 March 2012 the Bucharest Court of Appeal authorised her transfer to a psychiatric facility in Pădureni-Grajduri, a village located about twenty kilometres from Iaşi. At the time of the latest information available to the Court (9 November 2016), she was still detained there.
9.  On 11 April 2013 the applicant’s mother died. On 12 April 2013 the applicant lodged a request with the Iaşi District Court for leave to attend her funeral.
10.  On 23 May 2013 the court examined her request and refused to grant her leave. It pointed out that under Article 39 of the Mental Health Act (see paragraph 14 below) the restriction of liberty of mentally ill persons was justified for the protection of their health or safety or for the protection of others, and that under Article 49 of the same Act the facility was chosen so as to allow the mentally ill patient to be as close to home as possible. When applying the above provisions to the applicant’s situation, the court held as follows:
“Bearing in mind these legal provisions, the court considers that the safety of others prevails, the patient Solcan Luminiţa having been diagnosed with a mental illness which could potentially present a danger to the lives of others and their feelings of peace and confidence; for this reason, the request made by the patient shall be dismissed ...”
11.  The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against that decision. She claimed that the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 on the execution of sentences, which authorised the temporary interruption of a custodial sentence for family reasons, should also apply to her detention in a psychiatric facility. The prosecutor’s office argued that a measure of detention in a medical facility could not be assimilated to a custodial sentence and accordingly there was no legal basis for the interruption of the applicant’s involuntary hospitalisation in a psychiatric facility.
12.  By a final decision of 22 October 2013 the Iaşi County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal. It held that under Article 114 of the Criminal Code read in conjunction with Article 434 of the Code of Criminal Procedure her detention in a psychiatric facility could be either discontinued or replaced by an obligation to undergo outpatient mental health treatment after an assessment by medical experts. It concluded that the applicant’s request to interrupt her detention in a psychiatric facility had no basis in law and that no analogy could be drawn between her situation and the situation of a prison detainee. Accordingly, the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 authorising the temporary interruption of detention on family grounds were not applicable to her situation. Moreover, the court noted that in any event the applicant’s request was no longer valid as her mother’s funeral had already taken place.
RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW AND PRACTICE
13.  The relevant provisions of the Criminal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure, as in force at the relevant time, are set out in Filip v. Romania (no. 41124/02, §§ 30-31, 14 December 2006).
14.  Psychiatric detention is governed by the provisions of the Mental Health Act (Law no. 487 of 11 July 2002 on mental health and the protection of people with mental disorders) published in Official Gazette no. 589 of 8 August 2002. It was amended by Law no. 600/2004 and subsequently by Law no. 129/2012.
The Mental Health Act does not contain any provisions expressly authorising a judge to interrupt or suspend the involuntary hospitalisation of a mentally ill person.
15.  The Government attached to their observations three decisions made by the Buzau District Court (on 30 January 2014, 6 February and 27 March 2015 respectively) by which the applicants, who had all been admitted to a psychiatric facility for inpatient treatment, were allowed to attend the funerals of their family members. In all three case files there was medical evidence proving that they were able to attend. After assessing the particular circumstances of each applicant, the court granted them leave to attend their parents’ funerals. Their requests were examined by the court without undue delay so that they could attend. In one of the three cases the request was allowed on the condition that the applicant would be accompanied by medical staff and under police escort.

events.source_text: It pointed out that under Article 39 of the Mental Health Act (see paragraph 14 below) the restriction of liberty of mentally ill persons was justified for the protection of their health or safety or for the protection of others, and that under Article 49 of the same Act the facility was chosen so as to allow the mentally ill patient to be as close to home as possible.
events.event: It pointed out that under Article 39 of the Mental Health Act (see paragraph 14 below) the restriction of liberty of mentally ill persons was justified for the protection of their health or safety or for the protection of others, and that under Article 49 of the same Act the facility was chosen so as to allow the mentally ill patient to be as close to home as possible.

events.source_text: The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against that decision.
events.event: The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against that decision.

events.source_text: She claimed that the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 on the execution of sentences, which authorised the temporary interruption of a custodial sentence for family reasons, should also apply to her detention in a psychiatric facility.
events.event: She claimed that the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 on the execution of sentences, which authorised the temporary interruption of a custodial sentence for family reasons, should also apply to her detention in a psychiatric facility.

events.source_text: The prosecutor’s office argued that a measure of detention in a medical facility could not be assimilated to a custodial sentence and accordingly there was no legal basis for the interruption of the applicant’s involuntary hospitalisation in a psychiatric facility.
events.event: The prosecutor’s office argued that a measure of detention in a medical facility could not be assimilated to a custodial sentence and accordingly there was no legal basis for the interruption of the applicant’s involuntary hospitalisation in a psychiatric facility.

events.source_text: By a final decision of 22 October 2013 the Iaşi County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal.
events.event: By a final decision of 22 October 2013, the Iaşi County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal.

events.source_text: It held that under Article 114 of the Criminal Code read in conjunction with Article 434 of the Code of Criminal Procedure her detention in a psychiatric facility could be either discontinued or replaced by an obligation to undergo outpatient mental health treatment after an assessment by medical experts.
events.event: It held that under Article 114 of the Criminal Code read in conjunction with Article 434 of the Code of Criminal Procedure her detention in a psychiatric facility could be either discontinued or replaced by an obligation to undergo outpatient mental health treatment after an assessment by medical experts.

events.source_text: It concluded that the applicant’s request to interrupt her detention in a psychiatric facility had no basis in law and that no analogy could be drawn between her situation and the situation of a prison detainee.
events.event: It concluded that the applicant’s request to interrupt her detention in a psychiatric facility had no basis in law and that no analogy could be drawn between her situation and the situation of a prison detainee.

events.source_text: Accordingly, the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 authorising the temporary interruption of detention on family grounds were not applicable to her situation.
events.event: Accordingly, the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 authorising the temporary interruption of detention on family grounds were not applicable to her situation.

events.source_text: Moreover, the court noted that in any event the applicant’s request was no longer valid as her mother’s funeral had already taken place.
events.event: Moreover, the court noted that in any event the applicant’s request was no longer valid as her mother’s funeral had already taken place.

events.event: RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW AND PRACTICE

events.source_text: The relevant provisions of the Criminal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure, as in force at the relevant time, are set out in Filip v. Romania (no. 41124/02, §§ 30-31, 14 December 2006).
events.event: The relevant provisions of the Criminal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure, as in force at the relevant time, are set out in Filip v. Romania (no. 41124/02, §§ 30-31, 14 December 2006).

events.source_text: Psychiatric detention is governed by the provisions of the Mental Health Act (Law no. 487 of 11 July 2002 on mental health and the protection of people with mental disorders) published in Official Gazette no. 589 of 8 August 2002.
events.event: Psychiatric detention is governed by the provisions of the Mental Health Act (Law no. 487 of 11 July 2002 on mental health and the protection of people with mental disorders) published in Official Gazette no. 589 of 8 August 2002.

events.source_text: It was amended by Law no. 600/2004 and subsequently by Law no. 129/2012.
events.event: It was amended by Law no. 600/2004 and subsequently by Law no. 129/2012.

events.source_text: The Mental Health Act does not contain any provisions expressly authorising a judge to interrupt or suspend the involuntary hospitalisation of a mentally ill person.
events.event: The Mental Health Act does not contain any provisions expressly authorising a judge to interrupt or suspend the involuntary hospitalisation of a mentally ill person.

events.event: The Government attached to their observations three decisions made by the Buzau District Court (on 30 January 2014, 6 February and 27 March 2015 respectively) by which the applicants, who had all been admitted to a psychiatric facility for inpatient treatment, were allowed to attend the funerals of their family members.

events.source_text: In all three case files there was medical evidence proving that they were able to attend.
events.event: In all three case files, there was medical evidence proving that they were able to attend.

events.source_text: After assessing the particular circumstances of each applicant, the court granted them leave to attend their parents’ funerals.
events.event: After assessing the particular circumstances of each applicant, the court granted them leave to attend their parents’ funerals.

events.source_text: Their requests were examined by the court without undue delay so that they could attend.
events.event: Their requests were examined by the court without undue delay so that they could attend.

events.source_text: The applicant was born in 1969 and is currently in a psychiatric facility in PȚduȜeni-Grajduri.
events.event: The applicant was born in 1969 and is currently in a psychiatric facility in PȚduȜeni-Grajduri.

events.source_text: In 2005 she committed a murder in France. On 12 November 2007 the Mâcon County Court discontinued the criminal investigation against her on the grounds that she had committed the offence in a state of diminished responsibility.
events.event: She committed a murder in France in 2005 and the Mâcon County Court discontinued the criminal investigation against her on 12 November 2007 due to diminished responsibility.
events.event_what: committed a murder, discontinued the criminal investigation

events.source_text: The medical experts diagnosed her as suffering from paranoid schizophrenia and concluded that her acts had been the result of paranoid delusions.
events.event: Medical experts diagnosed her with paranoid schizophrenia and concluded that her actions were due to paranoid delusions.

events.source_text: The court ordered her placement in a psychiatric facility in France for an indefinite period of time.
events.event: The court ordered her placement in a psychiatric facility in France for an indefinite period of time.

events.source_text: In 2011 the applicant lodged a request to be transferred to a similar psychiatric facility in Romania in order to be closer to her mother, who lived in Iași.
events.event: The applicant lodged a request in 2011 to be transferred to a psychiatric facility in Romania to be closer to her mother in Iași.

events.source_text: By a decision of 30 March 2012 the Bucharest Court of Appeal authorised her transfer to a psychiatric facility in PȚduȜeni-Grajduri, a village located about twenty kilometres from Iași.
events.event: The Bucharest Court of Appeal authorised her transfer to a psychiatric facility in PȚduȜeni-Grajduri on 30 March 2012.

events.source_text: At the time of the latest information available to the Court (9 November 2016), she was still detained there.
events.event: She was still detained at the psychiatric facility in PȚduȜeni-Grajduri as of 9 November 2016.

events.source_text: On 11 April 2013 the applicant's mother died. On 12 April 2013 the applicant lodged a request with the Iași District Court for leave to attend her funeral.
events.event: The applicant's mother died on 11 April 2013, and she lodged a request with the Iași District Court on 12 April 2013 for leave to attend her funeral.
events.event_what: lodged a request for leave to attend the funeral

events.source_text: On 23 May 2013 the court examined her request and refused to grant her leave.
events.event: The court examined her request on 23 May 2013 and refused to grant her leave.
events.event_what: examined the request and refused to grant leave

events.source_text: It pointed out that under Article 39 of the Mental Health Act (see paragraph 14 below) the restriction of liberty of mentally ill persons was justified for the protection of their health or safety or for the protection of others, and that under Article 49 of the same Act the facility was chosen so as to allow the mentally ill patient to be as close to home as possible.
events.event: The court pointed out that the restriction of liberty under Article 39 of the Mental Health Act justified protecting health and safety, and Article 49 chose a facility near home.
events.event_what: pointed out justification for restricting liberty

events.source_text: When applying the above provisions to the applicant's situation, the court held as follows:
events.event: The court applied the above provisions to the applicant's situation and made a ruling.

events.source_text: 'Bearing in mind these legal provisions, the court considers that the safety of others prevails, the patient Solcan Luminișa having been diagnosed with a mental illness which could potentially present a danger to the lives of others and their feelings of peace and confidence; for this reason, the request made by the patient shall be dismissed ...'
events.event: 'Bearing in mind these legal provisions, the court considers that the safety of others prevails, the patient Solcan Luminișa having been diagnosed with a mental illness which could potentially present a danger to the lives of others and their feelings of peace and confidence; for this reason, the request made by the patient shall be dismissed ...'

events.source_text: The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against that decision.
events.event: The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against that decision.

events.source_text: She claimed that the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 on the execution of sentences, which authorised the temporary interruption of a custodial sentence for family reasons, should also apply to her detention in a psychiatric facility.
events.event: The applicant claimed that the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 on the execution of sentences authorising the temporary interruption of a custodial sentence for family reasons should apply to her detention in a psychiatric facility.

events.source_text: The prosecutor's office argued that a measure of detention in a medical facility could not be assimilated to a custodial sentence and accordingly there was no legal basis for the interruption of the applicant's involuntary hospitalisation in a psychiatric facility.
events.event: The prosecutor's office argued that a measure of detention in a medical facility couldn't be assimilated to a custodial sentence, so there was no legal basis for interrupting the applicant's involuntary hospitalization.

events.source_text: By a final decision of 22 October 2013 the Iași County Court dismissed the applicant's appeal.
events.event: The Iași County Court dismissed the applicant's appeal by a final decision on 22 October 2013.

events.source_text: It held that under Article 114 of the Criminal Code read in conjunction with Article 434 of the Code of Criminal Procedure her detention in a psychiatric facility could be either discontinued or replaced by an obligation to undergo outpatient mental health treatment after an assessment by medical experts.
events.event: The court held that her detention in a psychiatric facility could be discontinued or replaced with outpatient mental health treatment under Articles 114 and 434.

events.source_text: It concluded that the applicant's request to interrupt her detention in a psychiatric facility had no basis in law and that no analogy could be drawn between her situation and the situation of a prison detainee.
events.event: The court concluded that the applicant's request to interrupt her detention had no legal basis, and no analogy could be made with a prison detainee's situation.

events.source_text: Accordingly, the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 authorising the temporary interruption of detention on family grounds were not applicable to her situation.
events.event: The provisions of Law no. 275/2006 authorizing the temporary interruption of detention on family grounds were not applicable to her situation.

events.source_text: Moreover, the court noted that in any event the applicant's request was no longer valid as her mother's funeral had already taken place.
events.event: The court noted that the applicant's request was no longer valid because her mother's funeral had already occurred.

events.source_text: The relevant provisions of the Criminal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure, as in force at the relevant time, are set out in Filip v. Romania (no. 41124/02, §§ 30-31, 14 December 2006).
events.event: Relevant provisions of the Criminal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure are outlined in Filip v. Romania.

events.source_text: Psychiatric detention is governed by the provisions of the Mental Health Act (Law no. 487 of 11 July 2002 on mental health and the protection of people with mental disorders) published in Official Gazette no. 589 of 8 August 2002.
events.event: Psychiatric detention is governed by the provisions of the Mental Health Act.

events.source_text: It was amended by Law no. 600/2004 and subsequently by Law no. 129/2012.
events.event: The Mental Health Act was amended by Laws no. 600/2004 and no. 129/2012.

events.source_text: The Mental Health Act does not contain any provisions expressly authorising a judge to interrupt or suspend the involuntary hospitalisation of a mentally ill person.
events.event: The Mental Health Act lacks provisions for judges to interrupt or suspend involuntary hospitalization of mentally ill individuals.

events.source_text: The Government attached to their observations three decisions made by the Buzău District Court (on 30 January 2014, 6 February and 27 March 2015 respectively) by which the applicants, who had all been admitted to a psychiatric facility for inpatient treatment, were allowed to attend the funerals of their family members.
events.event: The Government attached three decisions from the Buzău District Court allowing applicants to attend family funerals while in psychiatric facilities.

events.source_text: In all three case files there was medical evidence proving that they were able to attend. After assessing the particular circumstances of each applicant, the court granted them leave to attend.
events.event: Medical evidence in all three cases proved their ability to attend funerals. The court assessed and granted leave for attendance after considering individual circumstances.

events.source_text: In one of the three cases the request was allowed on the condition that the applicant would be accompanied by medical staff and under police escort.
events.event: One case allowed attendance with a condition: being accompanied by medical staff and under police escort.

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, Declares the application admissible; Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention; Holds that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 × 2 of the Convention, EUR 6,000 (six thousand euros), to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement, in respect of non-pecuniary damage; that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amount at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points; Dismisses the remainder of the applicant's claim for just satisfaction.
events.event: The Court unanimously declared the application admissible, found a violation of Article 8 of the Convention, ordered the respondent State to pay EUR 6,000 in non-pecuniary damages within three months, with simple interest from then on at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank plus three percentage points. The remainder of the applicant's claim for just satisfaction was dismissed.
events.event_what: declared admissible, found violation, ordered payment, dismissed remainder

events.source_text: By a final decision of 22 October 2013 the Iaşi County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal. It held that under Article 114 of the Criminal Code read in conjunction with Article 434 of the Code of Criminal Procedure her detention in a psychiatric facility could be either discontinued or replaced by an obligation to undergo outpatient mental health treatment after an assessment by medical experts. It concluded that the applicant’s request to interrupt her detention in a psychiatric facility had no basis in law and that no analogy could be drawn between her situation and the situation of a prison detainee. Accordingly, the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 authorising the temporary interruption of detention on family grounds were not applicable to her situation. Moreover, the court noted that in any event the applicant’s request was no longer valid as her mother’s funeral had already taken place.
events.event: By a final decision of 22 October 2013 the Iaşi County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal.

events.source_text: The Government attached to their observations three decisions made by the Buzau District Court (on 30 January 2014, 6 February and 27 March 2015 respectively) by which the applicants, who had all been admitted to a psychiatric facility for inpatient treatment, were allowed to attend the funerals of their family members. In all three case files there was medical evidence proving that they were able to attend. After assessing the particular circumstances of each applicant, the court granted them leave to attend their parents’ funerals. Their requests were examined by the court without undue delay so that they could attend. In one of the three cases the request was allowed on the condition that the applicant would be accompanied by medical staff and under police escort.
